subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 240
msgSnippet: ... Really? Then why does JUnit report the Exception? Why is reporting more than one such assertion failure not more useful than only reporting the first? How
messageBody:
--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> No, and that is by design. One of the key requirements of unit
> testing is "Report for each test only 'pass' or 'fail'."

Really? Then why does JUnit report the Exception? Why is reporting more
than one such assertion failure not more useful than only reporting the
first? How is reporting two assertion failures different from a test
that manages to pack multiple booleans into a single assertTrue and
pass back the extra failure information in the message?

Is it really so evil to report more information in a failure that could
be used for solving the problem without invoking the debuggger. I hate
debuggers. Even fast and good ones take a lot of time and effort to get
to the problem (I know, I should use VAJ, but that's not how things
have evolved here; in part due to the integrated source control and
some initial problems with VM thrashing we had, VAJ got tossed). If I
get a complete assertion failure report, I might (and often have) been
able to fix the bug immediately.

I remain unconvinced that this feature is necessary, but it seems to me
that we should dismiss it so quickly simply because it's hard or it
doesn't fit our personal definition of unit test.

Regards,

Rob
